trans-unit.source: Certificate renewal guidance for Office 365 and Azure AD users.
trans-unit.target: Certificate renewal guidance for Office 365 and Azure AD users.

trans-unit.source: This article explains to Office 365 users how to resolve issues with emails that notify them about renewing a certificate.
trans-unit.target: This article explains to Office 365 users how to resolve issues with emails that notify them about renewing a certificate.

trans-unit.source: If you received an email or a portal notification asking you to renew your certificate for Office 365, this article is intended to help you resolve the issue and keep it from happening again.
trans-unit.target: If you received an email or a portal notification asking you to renew your certificate for Office 365, this article is intended to help you resolve the issue and keep it from happening again.

trans-unit.source: This article assumes that you are using AD FS as your federation server.
trans-unit.target: This article assumes that you are using AD FS as your federation server.

trans-unit.source: If you are using AD FS 2.0 or later, Office 365 and Azure AD will automatically update your certificate before it expires.
trans-unit.target: If you are using AD FS 2.0 or later, Office 365 and Azure AD will automatically update your certificate before it expires.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to perform any manual steps or run a script as a scheduled task.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to perform any manual steps or run a script as a scheduled task.

trans-unit.source: For this to work, both of the following default AD FS configuration settings must be in effect:
trans-unit.target: For this to work, both of the following default AD FS configuration settings must be in effect:

trans-unit.source: The AD FS property AutoCertificateRollover must be set to True, indicating that AD FS will automatically generate new token signing and token decryption certificates before the old ones expire.
trans-unit.target: The AD FS property AutoCertificateRollover must be set to True, indicating that AD FS will automatically generate new token signing and token decryption certificates before the old ones expire.

trans-unit.source: If the value is False, you are using custom certificate settings.
trans-unit.target: If the value is False, you are using custom certificate settings.

trans-unit.source: Go <linkText>here</linkText><title></title> for comprehensive guidance.
trans-unit.target: Go <linkText>here</linkText><title></title> for comprehensive guidance.

trans-unit.source: Your federation metadata must be available to the public internet.
trans-unit.target: Your federation metadata must be available to the public internet.

trans-unit.source: Here is how to check:
trans-unit.target: Here is how to check:

trans-unit.source: Verify that your AD FS installation is using automatic certificate rollover by executing the following command in a PowerShell command window on your primary federation server:
trans-unit.target: Verify that your AD FS installation is using automatic certificate rollover by executing the following command in a PowerShell command window on your primary federation server:

trans-unit.source: PS C:\> Get-ADFSProperties
trans-unit.target: PS C:\> Get-ADFSProperties

trans-unit.source: (note that if you are using AD FS 2.0, you will need to run Add-Pssnapin Microsoft.Adfs.Powershell first) else.
trans-unit.target: (note that if you are using AD FS 2.0, you will need to run Add-Pssnapin Microsoft.Adfs.Powershell first) else.

trans-unit.source: Check that your federation metadata is publicly accessible by navigating to the following URL from a computer on the public internet (off of the corporate network):
trans-unit.target: Check that your federation metadata is publicly accessible by navigating to the following URL from a computer on the public internet (off of the corporate network):

trans-unit.source: https://(yourFSname)/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml
trans-unit.target: https://(yourFSname)/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml

trans-unit.source: where (your_FS_name) is replaced with the federation service host name your organization uses, such as fs.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: where (your_FS_name) is replaced with the federation service host name your organization uses, such as fs.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: If you are able to verify both of these settings successfully, you do not have to do anything else.
trans-unit.target: If you are able to verify both of these settings successfully, you do not have to do anything else.

trans-unit.source: Example: https://fs.contos.com/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml
trans-unit.target: Example: https://fs.contos.com/federationmetadata/2007-06/federationmetadata.xml

trans-unit.source: If your AutoCertificateRollover property is set to False, you are using non-default AD FS certificate settings.
trans-unit.target: If your AutoCertificateRollover property is set to False, you are using non-default AD FS certificate settings.

trans-unit.source: The most common reason for this is that your organization manages AD FS certificates enrolled from an organizational certificate authority.
trans-unit.target: The most common reason for this is that your organization manages AD FS certificates enrolled from an organizational certificate authority.

trans-unit.source: In this case you need to renew and update your certificates yourself.
trans-unit.target: In this case you need to renew and update your certificates yourself.

trans-unit.source: Use the guidance <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Use the guidance <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If your AutocertificateRollover setting is True but your federation metadata is not publicly available, use the procedure below to ensure your certificates are updated both on premises and in the cloud:
trans-unit.target: If your AutocertificateRollover setting is True but your federation metadata is not publicly available, use the procedure below to ensure your certificates are updated both on premises and in the cloud:

trans-unit.source: verify that you are logged on to the primary AD FS server.
trans-unit.target: verify that you are logged on to the primary AD FS server.

trans-unit.source: Check the current signing certificates in AD FS by opening a PowerShell command window and running the following command:
trans-unit.target: Check the current signing certificates in AD FS by opening a PowerShell command window and running the following command:

trans-unit.source: PS C:\>Get-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing.
trans-unit.target: PS C:\>Get-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing.

trans-unit.source: (note that if you are using AD FS 2.0, you will need to run Add-Pssnapin Microsoft.Adfs.Powershell first)
trans-unit.target: (note that if you are using AD FS 2.0, you will need to run Add-Pssnapin Microsoft.Adfs.Powershell first)

trans-unit.source: Look at the command output at any certificates listed.
trans-unit.target: Look at the command output at any certificates listed.

trans-unit.source: If AD FS has generated a new certificate, you should see two certificates in the output: One for which the IsPrimary value is True and the NotAfter date is within 5 days, and one for which IsPrimary is False and NotAfter is about a year in the future.
trans-unit.target: If AD FS has generated a new certificate, you should see two certificates in the output: One for which the IsPrimary value is True and the NotAfter date is within 5 days, and one for which IsPrimary is False and NotAfter is about a year in the future.

trans-unit.source: If you only see one certificate, and the NotAfter date is within 5 days, you need to generate a new certificate by executing the following steps.
trans-unit.target: If you only see one certificate, and the NotAfter date is within 5 days, you need to generate a new certificate by executing the following steps.

trans-unit.source: To generate a new certificate, execute the following command at a PowerShell command prompt: PS C:\>Update-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing.
trans-unit.target: To generate a new certificate, execute the following command at a PowerShell command prompt: PS C:\>Update-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing.

trans-unit.source: Verify the update by running the following command again: PS C:\>Get-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing
trans-unit.target: Verify the update by running the following command again: PS C:\>Get-ADFSCertificate –CertificateType token-signing

trans-unit.source: Next, to manually update Office 365 federation trust properties, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: Next, to manually update Office 365 federation trust properties, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: Two certificates should be listed now, one of which has a NotAfter date of approximately one year in the future and for which the IsPrimary value is False.
trans-unit.target: Two certificates should be listed now, one of which has a NotAfter date of approximately one year in the future and for which the IsPrimary value is False.

trans-unit.source: Open the Microsoft Azure Active Directory Module for Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Open the Microsoft Azure Active Directory Module for Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Run $cred=Get-Credential.
trans-unit.target: Run $cred=Get-Credential.

trans-unit.source: When this cmdlet prompts you for credentials, type your cloud service administrator account credentials.
trans-unit.target: When this cmdlet prompts you for credentials, type your cloud service administrator account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Run Connect-MsolService –Credential $cred.
trans-unit.target: Run Connect-MsolService –Credential $cred.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet connects you to the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet connects you to the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Creating a context that connects you to the cloud service is required before running any of the additional cmdlets installed by the tool.
trans-unit.target: Creating a context that connects you to the cloud service is required before running any of the additional cmdlets installed by the tool.

trans-unit.source: If you are running these commands on a computer that is not the AD FS primary federation server, run Set-MSOLAdfscontext -Computer <AD FS primary server>, where <AD FS primary server> is the internal FQDN name of the primary AD FS server. This cmdlet creates a context that connects you to AD FS.
trans-unit.target: If you are running these commands on a computer that is not the AD FS primary federation server, run Set-MSOLAdfscontext -Computer <AD FS primary server>, where <AD FS primary server> is the internal FQDN name of the primary AD FS server. This cmdlet creates a context that connects you to AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Run Update-MSOLFederatedDomain –DomainName <domain>. This cmdlet updates the settings from AD FS into the cloud service and configures the trust relationship between the two.
trans-unit.target: Run Update-MSOLFederatedDomain –DomainName <domain>. This cmdlet updates the settings from AD FS into the cloud service and configures the trust relationship between the two.

trans-unit.source: If you need to support multiple top-level domains, such as contoso.com and fabrikam.com, you must use the SupportMultipleDomain switch with any cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: If you need to support multiple top-level domains, such as contoso.com and fabrikam.com, you must use the SupportMultipleDomain switch with any cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Support for Multiple Top Level Domains.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Support for Multiple Top Level Domains.

trans-unit.source: Finally, ensure all Web Application Proxy servers are updated with <linkText>Windows Server May 2014</linkText><title></title> rollup, otherwise the proxies may fail to update themselves with the new certificate, resulting in an outage.
trans-unit.target: Finally, ensure all Web Application Proxy servers are updated with <linkText>Windows Server May 2014</linkText><title></title> rollup, otherwise the proxies may fail to update themselves with the new certificate, resulting in an outage.
